posts.cooked:
I’m trying to install the photon vision library and use it but when I try doing the normal pip install, it tells me that the version of wpi I have installed, which is the latest one, is incompatible and I need to use an older version. image 2317×273 26.2 KB

image 2317×273 26.2 KB

image 2317×273 26.2 KB

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: robotpy-photonvision is no longer supported. Use photonlibpy instead.

That was the first thing I used when installing but vscode doesn’t seem to detect it. It works in the command line, but whenever I try declaring a camera it is giving me this error: image 750×128 9.93 KB

image 750×128 9.93 KB

image 750×128 9.93 KB

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked:
It appears that photonlibpy doesn’t export symbols in the top package, I had to do from photonlibpy.photonCamera import PhotonCamera . I’d point you to their API docs, but they don’t seem to have any.

If that isn’t your issue, take a look at vscode’s python environment docs, you have to have vscode pointing at the correct environment or pylance won’t detect it. Using Python Environments in Visual Studio Code

There’s also a useful discussion at Puzzled about photonlibpy that might help.

link_counts.title: Using Python Environments in Visual Studio Code

posts.cooked: That worked, thank you so much! I’ll take a look at that thread too.

posts.name: Davo
posts.cooked:
virtuald:

It appears that photonlibpy doesn’t export symbols in the top package, I had to do from photonlibpy.photonCamera import PhotonCamera .

I do find it rather bizarre that the single critical export of the package isn’t re-exported, and that users are expected to find an oddly named module within the package.

@gerthworm thoughts?

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked: Arbitrary choice, nothing in the design make it necessary to my knowledge.
